Department of Energy and Petroleum Engineering University of North Dakota Grand Forks ND 58202 United States One way to solve environmental and energy related problems is to use carbon dioxide as a raw material along with renewable H2 to make useful chemicals and goods from those alternative energy sources. Several compositions of xNi-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3 were used for CO2 methanation via the hydrothermal synthesis method. Techniques such as TEM, H2-TPD, XRD, SEM, and BET were used to study the influence of the mechanism of the catalyst during CO2 methanation. The best performance was obtained for the 1.5 % Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3 catalyst at 400 °C and normal atmospheric pressure, where the CO2 conversion efficiency and selectivity were 87.4 and 99.9 %, respectively. It was thought that the synergistic effects between the Ni active sites, the promoter, and the support were important for the high reactivity of the catalysts. These effects included better Ni dispersion and more CO2 adsorption sites due to the inclusion of MgO-Pr2O3. The promoted catalyst retained its high reactivity after 30 h on stream as observed during the stability test. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Key words Catalyst CO2 methanation Catalytic activity Nickel loading Selectivity Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Dry reformation of CH4 (DRM) for syngas production has garnered attention in recent years owing to its inherent advantages to mankind [1,2]. Furthermore, DRM concurrently involves the use of two major greenhouse gases (CH4 and CO2) to produce syngas with a H2/CO ratio of 1:1, which is nearly ideal for methanol synthesis and F-T reaction [3]. Ni-based catalysts have received great attention due to their underlying prospects in the DRM, however, the formation of mobile Ni sub-carbonyls, carbon deposits, and the sintering of nickel particles [4] can all lead to nickel catalyst deactivation at low temperatures. Additive addition to the Ni catalyst, altering the catalyst promoters/supports, and modifying the preparation procedures are some of the various approaches that have been tried to improve the catalytic activity and stability of nickel-based catalysts [5,6]. Several catalysts support have been studied for CO2 methanation, including SBA-15 [7], TUD-1 [8], Zeolite [9] etc. These supports are promising for CO2 methanation with Ni-catalysts; however, they have significant limitations. Traditional impregnation of Ni/SBA-15 results in poor particle dispersion and weak active phase-support interaction, which results in the dispersion of isolated Ni species during harsh reaction conditions despite possessing thick pore walls and high thermal stability [10–12]. Also, TUD-1 is less stable and less effective for CO2 methanation compared to the MCM-41 catalyst-support, although, the mechanical stability of Ni/Zeolite, Ni/TUD-1 and Ni/SBA-15 may be a concern, especially under high-pressure and high temperature conditions [13]. The structure of the catalyst may undergo changes over time, thus affecting its catalytic activity and performance [14]. Like most silica-based materials, MCM-41 is frequently employed in catalysis due to its exceptional characteristics such as controllable morphologies [15], easy surface functionalization, flexible heteroatom compositions [16], unique channel structure, larger specific surface area [17], good thermal stability and biocompatibility, tunable/large pore size, strong adsorption capacity and narrow pore size distribution [18]. MCM-41 may be the best mesoporous adsorbent model for studying adsorption characteristics. Du et al. [19] used a Ni/MCM-41 catalyst with 1–3 wt.% Ni generated in situ to achieve 96 % methane selectivity at 400 °C under typical ambient conditions. Hydrothermally synthesized Ni/MCM-41 was used by Zhang et al. [20] to produce synthetic natural gas by syngas methanation. Both the CO conversion and the methane production remained stable at close to 100 and 82 % throughout the 100-h stability test. According to literature [21], the highest methane selectivity attained using Ni/MCM-41 was 96 %; hence, there is a need to further improve the selectivity of methane as well as CO2 conversion with the help of suitable promoter(s). Promoting metal oxides like Pr2O3 and MgO can enhance catalyst stability by providing more active sites and strengthening metal support interactions. Pr2O3 enhances thermal stability by generating oxygen vacancies, while MgO improves the thermal stability of Ni-catalyst and CH4 dry reforming in MCM-41. This study reports the use of Ni as an active component on mesoporous silica MCM-41 for the dry reforming of CH4. Hydrothermal synthesis was used to prepare Ni/MCM-41 with varying Ni loadings for CO2 methanation reactions. The oxides were evenly mixed to create a Ni- MCM-41-MgO/ Pr2O3 solid solution. MgO/Pr2O3 was doped into the Ni/MCM-41 system as promoters to maintain the stability of Ni nanoparticles. This is an unprecedented use of MgO-Pr2O3 as a promoter for Ni/MCM-41-based catalyst. To examine the physico-chemical characteristics of the catalyst, including catalyst performance, surface, and bulk properties, various methods were used to investigate the catalysts. The purpose of this investigation was to examine the impact of molar ratio and temperature of reactants on three key factors: (i) CO2 conversion, (ii) CH4 yield/selectivity within the context of catalyst performance and (iii) catalyst activity. 2 Experimental procedure 2.1 Reagents The materials used consist of TEOS (C8H20O4Si Merck, P99 %), (Mg (NO3)2.6H2O), (Pr(NO3)3.6H2O) salts and Ni(NO3)2.6H2O which were purchased as silicon precursor, Mg, praseodymium, and nickel precursors, respectively. NaOH and CTAB were prepared as soft templates to regularize the media pH along the synthetic routes. 2.2 The use of hydrothermal synthesis method for the preparation of nickel incorporated on MCM-41 In the synthesis of Ni incorporated MCM-41 catalysts, pure TEOS (C8H20O4Si, 99 %), by Sigma Aldrich and CTAB, and 99.5 % pure C16H33(CH3)3NBr by Merck were used as silica sources and surfactant. The Ni mixed with MCM-41 was synthesized following Zhang et al. [22] procedure with little modifications. MCM-41 was synthesized in alkaline (CTAB and TEOS) as silica source. 3.0 g of CTAB was dissolved in 80 mL of deionized H2O and stirred for 1 h at 45 °C. Furthermore, 6.5 g of TEOS was mixed with 15 mL of deionized water which contained 1.2 g of urea was added dropwise into the resulting solution. The overall mixture was stirred continuously at 27 °C for 1 h. A solution containing 1 g of nickel (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O) was admixed with the solution containing the TEOS mixture and continuously stirred. The solution's pH was adjusted to 9. The molar composition of the chemicals is xNi:1.4TEOS:1.2CTAB:0. 32NaOH:100H2O. The obtained yellow-green mixtures were aged at 28 °C for 2 1 2 h under constant stirring and then transferred into an autoclave and crystallized statically for 24 h at 140 °C. The mixture was allowed to cool at 27 °C and centrifuged to obtain the solids. The obtained solid was washed with deionized H2O and further dried in an oven at 105 °C for 12 h. The obtained solid was calcined at a heating rate of 5 h, at 3 °C/min and 600 °C. A series of %Ni incorporated MCM-41 molar ratios, was prepared. Pr(NO3)3 6H2O (Aldrich, 99.96 %) and Mg(NO3)2 6H2O (Aldrich, 99.97 %) were used as promoters. The catalyst-promoters (Pr2O3: MgO (1:1) were added to the prepared catalysts. The incorporation of these promoters was carried out by adding a fixed proportion of Pr and Mg salts (1:1) to the 1.5, 2 wt. % Ni incorporated MCM-41 catalyst-solution after TEOS addition. After stirring for an hour, a yellow-green powdered material that was separated/recovered after filtration, was washed and dried; and the calcination procedure was repeated. Lastly, the catalysts were labeled Ni-MCM-41, Ni-MCM-41/MgO, 1.5 % Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3, 2 % Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3. 2.3 Characterization of the catalysts The ICP-OES (Spectro Blue ICP) was used to determine the quantity of metal present in the synthesized materials. 20 mg of the catalyst was dissolved in 3 mL concentrated sulphuric acid at 250 °C and 1.0 mL acid solution which comprise of equimolar HF, H2O, and HNO3. The XRD was used to investigate the crystallinity of the promoter/support and the crystal structure of the Ni particles. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained using αCuKa radiation at 1.54 Å on a Bruker Phaser diffractometer. From 10 to 80°, the 2 h angles were observed at a step size of 0.02° and at a rate of 1.0 s/step. Micromeritics ASAP 2020 was used to carry out hydrogen chemisorption. For H2 chemisorption at 35 °C, 50 mg catalyst was typically placed onto the quartz U-tube reactor and reduced at 600 °C (5 °C per minute for 4 h), and vented at 580 °C, before disposing the chemisorbed species. On the Auto-Chem II 2910 equipment, CO2-TPD was performed. After 30 min of reduction at 700 C in 10 % H2/Ar, 70 mg of the calcined catalyst was cooled to 60 °C in a flow of pure Ar. The catalyst was then exposed to a feed of 10 % CO2/argon at 40 mL/minute for 1 h before being purged with pure argon to remove the carbon dioxide that had been physically adsorbed on it. The catalyst was heated to 650 °C in an atmosphere of pure argon while the desorbed CO2 was observed using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). At 196 °C, a Quadrasorb SI was used to profile the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherm. Degassing at 300 °C for 3 h was performed prior to the measurement.The Barrett-Joynerr-Halenda (BJH) desorption isotherm model was used to determine the catalysts pore volume, whereas the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method was used to determined specific surface area and pore size. The X-ray source Kratos DLD-AXIS Ultra with a monochromatic Al Kα gun having the energy of 1490 eV, 220 W with a hemispherical analyzer was used to determine the XPS spectra. The XPS analyzer was set to 80 eV. The reduced material was subjected to the same reduction condition used in the response test, which was an ex-situ reduction at 500 °C under pure hydrogen for an hour. All catalysts were reduced ex-situ for 1 h at 700 °C in a flow of clean hydrogen gas before being transferred to the sample cell and exposed to air. Each binding energy was verified in relation to the unanticipated C1 peaks at 285 eV. The SEM (FEI SIRION-100) scans of the surfaces were used to examine the different morphologies. TEM, the Philips-FEI-G2F30 Transmission electron microscopy was used to measure distributions and particle sizes. A 300 kV FEI Titan with a Cs correction cube was used to take measurements. In order to evenly distribute the sample over the Cu support grid, it was first pulverized and then sonicated in C2H5OH. 2.4 Catalyst performance Fixed-bed quartz reactors with stainless steel tubes (40 cm long, 10 mm internal diameter) were used to test the catalysts in an aerated atmosphere. At a weight space velocity of 12,000 mL/g/h, the reaction mixture comprising of gases with a 3:1:1 ratio of n(H2):n(CO):n(N2) was charged into the reactor with 400 mg of catalyst (sieve fraction 75 mesh) in the center. Each test was preceded by a one-hour in-situ reduction of the catalysts using pure hydrogen gas (50 mL/min) at 500 °C, and thereafter, a helium flush was conducted. A gas chromatograph (Agilent 7820) with a TCD was used to perform real-time analysis of the exit gases. Eqs. (1) and (2) were used to determine the carbon monoxide conversion (Xco) and methane selectivity. (1) C O 2 C o n v e r s i o n = C O 2 f l o w r a t e ( i n ) − C O 2 f l o w r a t e ( o u t ) C O 2 f l o w r a t e ( i n ) (2) C O 2 S e l e c t i v i t y = C H 4 f l o w r a t e ( o u t ) C H 4 f l o w r a t e ( o u t ) + C O f l o w r a t e ( o u t ) Note: All tests were conducted in three trials for each catalyst 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural analysis The XRD patterns of Pr2O3-enhanced MgO-MCM-41 with different% nickel loading are as illustrated in Fig. 1 a, where the MCM-41 and MgO-MCM-41 supports only show a broad peak at 2 θ = 29.1° (JCPDS reference number 87 -0712), thus confirming that an amorphous phase is associated with the silica mesoporous structure. Since the XRD test is unable to detect the magnesia phase, one can infer that it occurred amorphously on the catalysts' support [23,24]. Peaks of cubic-structured Ni could be seen for all the promoted/unprompted Ni catalysts (Fig. 1a) at 2 θ = 35°, 40°, and 47° (JCPDS reference number 04 -0850). Minor broadening and distortions in the diffraction peaks of all catalyst types, particularly the 1.5 % Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3 sample, indicate that the hybrids were synthesized successfully. The physically combined and core-shell samples of 1.5 % Ni-MCM-41 and MgO-Pr2O3 also showed peak characteristics of the MCM-41structure, albeit, they had lower intensities due to the low percentage of the constituents in the composite. It was also shown that the 1.5 % Ni-MCM-41/MgO- Pr2O3 core-shell is not influenced by the composition of the composite due to the presence of the catalyst's promoter and support (MgO and PbrO3); these observations are consistent with those of Refs. [25–26]. The formation of homogenous solid solutions or highly distributed crystallites may account for the occurrence of diffraction peaks for the MgO and Pr2O3 [26,27]. Thus, it is likely that the Pr3+ and Mg2+ were integrated into the catalysts' crystal structure, thus creating a homogenous solid solution [28] which in turn results in a significant shift in the prominent diffraction peak (2 θ = 29.1°) of MgO, and Pr2O3 thus promoting and supporting the material (MCM-41). The obtained result is in line with the findings of Ref. [7]. It has been proven that O2 vacancy sites and mobile electron and hole concentrations can be optimized by incorporating valence cations (such as Pr3+ and Mg2+) into the crystal structure of the catalyst [12,17]. The catalyst crystallite size was calculated using the Scherrer equation for all the prepared supports and promoters. When Ni was doped, it altered the crystallite size of the supporting materials. Substitution/replacement of Ni ions and the production of O2 vacancy sites [29] are evidenced by these findings, thus indicating the formation of solid solutions. The deposition of Mg and Pr onto the supports also altered the size of the Ni-loading crystallites, which may have been caused by the melting of Pr species during the calcination process whilst bringing about a significant reduction in the specific surface area of the catalysts. 3.2 BET analysis The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms for Ni-MCM-41, Ni-MCM-41/MgO, 1.5 % Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3, and 2 % Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3 are as shown in Fig. 1b. In accordance with the IUPAC classifications, all samples have type IV adsorption curves, which are indicative of mesoporous condensation via capillaries bearing hexagonal cylindrical pathways [30]. Above a P/P0 of 0.3, the hysteresis loop can be attributed to MCM-41, due to its incorporation into Ni loading which affects the overall pore volume and surface area of the catalysts. Furthermore, the interaction between Ni species and MCM-41 support can influence the accessibility of the pores, thus, pore blocking or modification on the surface chemistry due to the presence of Ni may be reflected in the geometry of the resulting isotherm. After loading Ni, the supports, and promoters onto the material, the MCM-41 maintains its highly organized mesoporous structure, which is particularly useful. Data from N2 adsorption-desorption investigation for all catalysts together with their corresponding average pore diameters alongside their BET surface areas, and pore volumes are presented in Table 1 . The results show that once the MCM-41 support and MgO/Pr2O3 were added to the Ni catalyst, the BET surface area and pore volume were reduced from 799.9 m2 /g and 0.55 cm3/g, respectively, to 511.3 m2 /g and 0.43 cm3/g, for the Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3 catalyst. MgO is known for its high surface area and porosity. The incorporation of MgO as a promoter may lead to a catalyst with increased surface area, which can positively impact the adsorption of CO2 molecules. The porous structure may also facilitate better diffusion of reactants and products. The presence of Pr2O3 contributes to the development of a porous catalyst structure, which potentially improves the overall catalyst activity and selectivity [24,31,32]. As seen in Table 1, the surface area of the catalysts with higher nickel contents were observed to have decreased compared to those of the Pr2O3-promoted catalysts. This observation suggests that the doping of Ni ions into the Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3 structure was successful [33]. The predicted high temperature resistance of this catalyst against agglomeration and coking of nanoparticles of nickel is a notable characteristic. A double hysteresis loop in the catalyst (1.5 % Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3, and 2 % Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3) may be indicative of a complex phenomenon occurring during the catalysts’ activities, which is an indication that the catalysts underwent different processes during the forward and reverse reactions, and these processes may not be instantaneous. Thus, some factors such as temperature, adsorption/desorption dynamics, multistep reactions, catalyst surface reconstruction, and redox processes may have influenced the process [34]. The isotherm curve is classified as Type IV, which is mostly influenced by the presence of mesopores. The hysteresis loop corresponds to Type A, indicating the presence of cylindrical pores [16,29]. The loop is relatively narrow. It exhibits a hybrid nature, with traits that are intermediate between type H1 and H2. H1 hysteresis is distinguished by very parallel adsorption and desorption stages, while H2 hysteresis typically exhibits a desorption branch that is steeper than the adsorption branch [13,22,29]. 3.3 SEM characterization Fig. 2 a–d shows the variation of catalyst surface morphology. The catalysts have surfaces that are characterized by roughness and porosity with features of discernible tiny particles. This surface morphology proved to be advantageous in facilitating the methanation process of CO2. The catalysts used for the methanation of CO2 are depicted in Fig. 2a–d, which correspond to Ni-MCM-41, Ni-MCM-41/MgO, 1.5 % Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3, and 2 % Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3, respectively. The production of spherical particles was seen in the MCM-41 material, and this spherical shape was maintained in the composite materials. All catalysts exhibited a rough surface with consistent shape. The SEM image of the 1.5 % Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3 revealed a surface that exhibited greater uniformity. The XRD patterns indicate that the Ni particles are equally dispersed throughout the catalyst. The addition of MgO-Pr2O3 as a promoter can influence the particle size and dispersion of the catalyst. MgO nanoparticles, when incorporated into the catalyst, contribute to a finer and more dispersed structure. This enhanced dispersion provides a higher surface area, which in turn offers more active sites for CO2 adsorption and subsequent methanation reactions. The combination of MgO and Pr2O3 in a catalyst system may lead to synergistic effects on morphology. The unique properties of each promoter, such as the basicity of MgO and redox activity of Pr2O3, may work together to create a catalyst with an optimized morphology for CO2 methanation. However, it is worth noting that the 1.5 % Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3 catalyst had a reduced pore volume compared to the catalyst containing 2 % Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3. The equal distribution and lack of sintering observed in the Ni particles can be attributed to the relatively low concentration of Ni particles compared to the abundant surface area of the catalyst's support. Additionally, the results indicated that Ni was either been incorporated within the structure of MCM-41 or had assumed the form of nanoscale Ni particles on the surface of MCM-41. The obtained results corroborate the findings of Refs. [6,13]. This suggests that successful distribution of Ni on the highly porous spherical MCM-41 material was accomplished. The presence of higher Ni content resulted in the observable aggregation of Ni particles, which is consistent with the results from XRD and BET investigations. The results obtained from the structural equation modeling (SEM) analysis align with the findings reported in Refs. [11,26]. The included photos serve as visual representations of the diverse pores present within the catalysts utilized in the process of methanation of carbon dioxide. 3.4 XPS analysis The XPS spectra of the prepared catalysts are as shown in Fig. 3 a. Ni (2p) XPS spectra of the catalyst did not display peaks at 853–854 eV, thus, indicating the absence of Ni. The Ni 2p peaks (centered at 858 eV) are in the range of 850–890 eV [3,20]. Upon loading nickel, the binding energy of the Ni (2p) electron in the catalyst decreased as a result of the electron/charge donation to nickel. Therefore, it is reasonable to anticipate an increase in the level of negative charge density in Ni (2p) XPS spectra. The obtained Pr2O3 spectra were deconvoluted into two peaks centered at 859.1 and 876.3 eV, and the Ni 2p1/2 spectrum was deconvoluted into two peaks centered at 858.1 and 876.1 eV as shown in Fig. 3b. The peaks located at about 231.8 eV and 235.9 eV (Fig. 3c) originated from the MCM-41 species [41]. The binding energy of the Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3 peaks increased as compared to that of Ni-MCM-41 which may be due to their pore volumes and the addition of catalyst support/promoter. All the Ni 2p1/2 peaks exhibited similar trends, indicating that the interactions between Ni atoms and the MCM-41 carriers were enhanced [19]. The XPS spectra of MgO were almost like those of Pr2O3 (Fig. 3d). The basic sites on the MgO surface can facilitate the adsorption of CO2 and provide active sites for the subsequent reactions. The combination of MgO and Pr2O3 in a catalyst system can lead to synergistic interactions with higher effects. The unique properties of each promoter may complement one another, thus resulting in improved overall catalyst performance. Two principal peaks in the Ni 2p1/2 spectrum (Fig. 3b) centered at 858.1 and 878.2 eV confirmed the metallic state of Ni in Ni-MCM-41. While the observed Ni 2p doublet with the binding energy of 888.9 eV, may be attributed to the Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3 on the surface of Ni nanoparticles; the existence of a strong interaction between the Ni, MCM-41, MgO and Pr2O3 is also evident. The binding energies of 1.5 % Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3 and Ni-MCM-41 are illustrated in Fig. 3c, where the lower binding energy of the 1.5 % Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3 (629.84 m2/g) is attributed to the surface area of the catalyst compared with that of Ni-MCM-41 (799.9 m2/g), which is in line with the observations in Ref. [22]. 3.5 H2 temperature programmed (H2TPD) desorption The change in H2 adsorption behavior due to Pr2O3-MgO incorporation can be understood by H2-TPD. Catalyst profiles can be seen as Fig. S1 of the supplemental file. Two peaks of Ni desorption are visible in the observed TPD patterns of the catalysts. The first at 100 °C, is associated with the MCM-41 species that is weakly supported on the Ni surface. The addition of MCM-41species to the 1.5 % Ni with the support of MgO-Pr2O3, lowered the reduction temperature and increased the reducibility of the Ni particles, as indicated by peaks in the 500 °C range which can be attributed to the strongly supported MCM-41species on the deep hollow or defect sites of metallic Ni surface [10]. MCM-41 has varying effects on Ni adsorption, and as Ni loading increases, the total amount of MCM-41 adsorption decreases. Since the donation of electrons can increase the electronic charge of the metallic atoms' orbitals; Fig. S1 also shows that the strongly supported MCM-41species are the main adsorption phases on the catalysts bearing MgO and Pr2O3 as support and promoter, while the weakly adsorbed MCM-41species are the main ones for catalysts with more Ni content. There is a definite possibility of the reduction of Pr2O3 under a H2 stream during H2-TPR, and the extent and temperature of reduction depend on various conditions such as the nature of the oxide and the experimental conditions. Pr2O3, is a compound where praseodymium is in the +3-oxidation state. Reduction under a hydrogen (H2) stream during TPR involves the reaction of H2 with the oxide to reduce it to a lower oxidation state i.e., often PrO2 or even Pr. Pr2O3, is a solid where praseodymium is in the +3-oxidation state; the sample is exposed to a stream of H2 gas. In a TPR experiment, the temperature usually increases gradually. The H2 molecules dissociate on the surface of the oxide, and the resulting H2 atoms are adsorbed onto the oxide. The H2 atoms then react with the praseodymium ions in the oxide, which then lead to a reduction in oxidation state (Eq. (3)) (3) P r 2 O 3 + H 2 → P r 2 O 2 + H 2 O This reaction signifies the reduction of Pr(III) to Pr(II), forming praseodymium(II) oxide. Further reduction may even occur (Eq. (4)): (4) P r 2 O 2 + H 2 → 2 Pr + H 2 O Eq. (4) presents the reduction of Pr(II) to praseodymium metal. The reduction process is monitored by measuring changes in the physical properties or signals, such as the release of water vapor, changes in electrical conductivity, or other relevant signals, depending on the experimental setup. 3.6 CO2 temperature-programmed desorption The influence of basicity on catalysts with varying morphologies was characterized by CO2-TPD. Due to the acidic nature of CO2, the basicity of these catalysts has significant impacts on the catalyst performance during methanation. Accordingly, the catalyst's activity, chemisorption, and reaction of reactive gases can all be improved at these very basic sites [28]. The CO2-TPD profile shows distinct desorption peaks at temperatures corresponding to the distribution of catalyst basic sites ranging from weak, moderate, and strong to extremely strong at 99–200 °C, 250–350 °C, 600–800 °C, and >800 °C, respectively [29,30]. At 99 °C and 300 °C, the CO2 desorption peaks of the four distinct morphologies of MCM-41 supports correspond to the weakly basic sites and the medium strong basic sites, respectively as shown in Fig. S2. The basic sites on the MgO surface can facilitate the adsorption of CO2 and provide active sites for the subsequent reactions. The presence of the combined promoters (MgO-Pr2O3) may allow for the optimization of the reaction conditions such as temperature and pressure so as to achieve improved efficiency. The Ni loading influences a significant number of weakly basic sites, and high temperature desorption peaks of CO2 are translated to low temperature in the Ni catalysts. CO2 adsorption at 100 °C was found to be highest for Ni-MCM-41, followed by Ni-MCM-41/MgO, the 1.5 % Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3, and finally the 2 % Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3. Therefore, it may be deduced that the Ni-MCM-41 catalyst's basic site density facilitates electron transport from the support to Ni thereby enhancing the catalyst's activity. For CO2 uptake, there was not much difference in the amount of CO2-uptake in the catalysts except for the case of the 2 % Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3; this is an indication that at higher Ni loading, the CO2 uptake tends to reduce as shown in the profile of the 2 % Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3 which may be due to low catalyst surface area (as already presented in Table 1), weak catalyst – CO2 interactions, poor dispersion of active sites, inadequate catalyst activation etc. This is an indication higher Ni loading had a significant effect on the catalysts. 3.7 Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) Ni particles can be seen as tiny agglomerates around the supports in the TEM images. The catalyst's veil-like structure, which is indicative of greater Ni dispersion, was readily apparent. In contrast, the nano-sized structural supports are made up of rough, spherical particles that are only around 50 nm in diameter. Within the crystalline domains and on the surface of the particle-support, the nickel particles may be seen as tiny dark dots. Within either the traditional or nano-structured series, the catalyst-morphologies were almost identical. As shown in Fig. S3, the inter-crystalline gaps and gaps between the nano-sized crystals can be attributed to the wide distribution of mesopores determined by N2-physisorption . Also, the size difference between the conventional and nano-structured series of Ni particles is clearly visible in the particles identified. These findings corroborate those of the XRD analysis. Catalysts with Pr2O3 as support, such as those of 1.5 % Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3 and 2 % Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3, showed better dispersion than the Ni-MCM-41 and Ni-MCM-41/MgO samples. Because of the MCM-41, the 1.5 % Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3 catalyst displayed a spherical shape with high dispersion on the MgO-Pr2O3 support [29]. Previous findings suggested the possibility that Ni may aggregate in the overall catalyst's mass [30,31]. The high-resolution images of all the catalysts revealed that Ni assumed a globular morphology on MCM-41. The HR-TEM images of Ni revealed a distinct separation of crystal indices. The lattice fringes in the high-resolution images have varying spacing of 4.88, 2.03, 2.16 and 2.21 Å, respectively. Previous reports on Ni/Al2O3 and Ni2P/SiO2 catalysts also agree with the reported d-spacing observed in the current study. 3.8 NH3-TPD reduction behavior of catalyst samples The adsorption/activation of NH3 and surface acidity can be effectively investigated using NH3-TPD. As described in Fig. S4, the Ni-MCM-41 catalyst's NH3-TPD profile exhibits peaks at temperature ranges of 50 −110 °C (I), 110–150 °C (II), and 150–250 °C (III); all of which can be attributed to the adsorption of NH3 on weak and medium-strong acid-sites. It was observed that the 1.5 % Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3 exhibited a higher number of acid sites on its surface. The desorption peaks observed at low temperatures (referred to as region I) were attributed to the presence of NH3-coordinated Lewis acid sites. On the other hand, the desorption peaks observed at medium and high temperatures (referred to as regions II and III) were attributed to the desorption of NH3 that had been adsorbed on Bronsted acid sites [11]. When MgO and Pr2O3 are present to provide support and promotion, the surface acidity of the Ni-MCM-41 catalyst increases even further. MgO can enhance the adsorption of CO2 on the catalyst surface, thus making it more accessible for reaction with hydrogen to form methane. The highest desorption temperatures of NH3 adsorbed on Lewis and Bronsted acids were 110 and 150 °C, respectively, for the 1.5 % Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3 catalysts [33]. The reaction is aided by the increased number and improved quality of acid sites. According to Table 1 SBET values, the 1.5 % Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3 catalyst has a higher number of acid sites on its surface, as measured by the higher number of m2/g of desorbed NH3 compared to the other catalysts with lower or higher% Ni loading on MgO-Pr2O3. As catalyst loading increased, the peak decreased. For the most part, the 1.5 % Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3 sample contains the most acid sites and the strongest acidity, thus indicating the existence of a strong synergistic interaction between MCM-41 and Ni that can considerably promote the methanation reaction [24]. Since the methanation reaction was sped up due to the presence of acid sites on the surface, it follows that the addition of MCM-41, MgO, and Pr2O3 to the 1.5 % Ni catalyst might have a profoundly beneficial effect on these sites. These results justify the works of Refs. [21,26]. 3.9 Catalyst activity 3.9.1 Effect of Pr2O3 content on the catalysts Fig. 4 a–c depicts the relationship between the reaction temperature and the effect of Pr2O3 addition on catalyst performance during the CO2 methanation process. Pr2O3 is known for its redox properties, and its presence can promote redox reactions involved in CO2 methanation. Pr2O3 can increase the catalytic activity of a catalyst by providing additional active sites or by participation in the reaction mechanism step. All the catalysts improved in carbon dioxide conversion and methane selectivity as the temperature was raised from 320 to 480 °C, whereas CO selectivity was drastically reduced. Above 480 °C, however, methane selectivity and carbon dioxide conversion of all the catalysts diminished significantly, while the carbon monoxide selectivity increased. The selectivity for methane improved and CO2 conversion was improved by the presence of the catalyst (Fig. 4a). Since Pr2O3-MgO was introduced, the optimum temperature for CO2 conversion and methane selectivity was reduced. The thermodynamic investigation by Zhou et al. [34] shows that CO2 methanation is exothermic, with the Gibbs free energy change ( Δ r G m θ ) going from negative to positive at elevated temperature. The ( Δ r G m θ ) goes from −40 to 0 kJ/mol as the temperature goes from 480 to 660 °C. Therefore, high temperatures may prevent CO2 methanation. In addition, high temperatures can cause sintering of active sites of the catalyst and increase the tendency for carbon deposition on the catalysts which may in turn impede catalyst activity [5]. At high temperatures, the CH4 selectivity drops (Fig. 4b) while the CO selectivity increases (Fig. 4c), possibly because of an increase in the steam reforming process of methane [35]. 3.9.2 Effect of different GHSV Selectivity for carbon dioxide, methane, and CO conversion by Ni/MCM-41 and 1.5 %Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3 under atmospheric condition at 400 °C are shown in Fig. S5a and b at varying GHSV from 3000 mL/g/h to 21,000 mL/g/h. Furthermore, the addition of Pr2O3-MgO to the nickel catalyst makes it far more active compared to an unpromoted nickel catalyst under those same GHSVs. Compared to the conversion and selectivity of 40.1 % and 39.4 % that were obtained for Ni/MCM-41 at GHSV of 3000 mL/g/h, the 1.5 % Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3 catalyst gave higher carbon dioxide conversion of 69.66 % and CH4 selectivity of 98.87 % at GHSVs of 3000 and 9000 mL/g/h, respectively. By virtue of a decreasing contact time between the catalysts and feed gases, carbon dioxide conversion decreased with an increase in GHSV for the promoted/unprompted catalysts. Interestingly, the rate at which carbon dioxide conversion decreases for the 1.5 % Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3 is undoubtedly slower than that of Ni/MCM-41. In addition, as demonstrated in Fig. S5b, at a 1.5 %.Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3 concentration, the CH4 selectivity was dramatically increased compared to carbon monoxide selectivity. It is worthy to note that increasing the GHSV from 3000 mL/g/h to 21,000 mL/g/h did not affect the CH4 selectivity, which was maintained at an average of 98 % for the 1.5 % Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3. The results show that the addition of Pr2O3-MgO considerably improved the catalytic activity of Ni/MCM-41 and increased its tolerance for a wide range of reaction conditions. The obtained result agrees with the findings in Ref. [8]. 3.9.3 Stability test At a temperature of 400 °C under atmospheric pressure and a GHSV of 9000 mL/g/h, the stability of 1.5 %Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3 and Ni/MCM-41were tested. The CO2 conversion plotted against on-stream reaction time is shown in Fig. 5 a. As the Ni-MCM-41 spent more time in the reactor, its CO2 conversion rate dropped from 52.90 % after 3 h to 45.41 % after 30 h. At the same time, the activity and CO2 conversion of the Pr2O3-promoted catalyst remained constant at around 87.4 %. MgO can contribute to the stability of the catalyst, thus preventing the sintering or agglomeration of the catalyst's active sites over time. Pr2O3 can increase the activity of the catalyst by providing additional active sites or by influencing the reaction mechanism. Furthermore, adding Pr2O3-MgO to Ni-MCM-41 not only caused an increase in the catalyst's activity but also made the catalyst more stable. After 30 h of time on stream (TOS), the stability of the most active catalyst (1.5 %Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3) was assessed at the same experimental conditions. The methane selectivity was stabilized at 99.9 %. This is an indication that the 1.5 %Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3 can deliver a stable and optimal performance, which can last for an extended period. 3.10 Methanation of 1.5 % Ni-MCM-41/MgO- Pr2O3 catalysts 3.10.1 In situ drifts analysis A DRIFTS study was performed to investigate the intermediate products and mechanism of photo-thermally catalyzed CO2 methanation. This investigation involved subjecting 1.5 % Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3 to a continuous flow of the H2/CO2 at a temperature span of 150 to 350 °C. It was also possible to observe the changes in surface species during the hydrogenation and CO2 adsorption processes. CO2 methanation over the 1.5 % Ni-MCM-41/MgO- Pr2O3 catalyst was measured using the operando DRIFT as shown in Fig. 7a. Bicarbonates (1623, 1415, and 1221 cm−1), monodentate carbonates (1520, 1451, and 1334 cm−1), and bidentate formates (2868, 1573, 1383, and 1354 cm−1) are all seen in the 1.5 % Ni-MCM-41/MgO- Pr2O3 at 150 °C (Fig. 6 (a)) (Table 2 ). Up to 200 °C, the proportion of bidentate formates increased significantly, whereas the proportions of bidentate bicarbonates and monodentate carbonates dropped. Nevertheless, due to their instability and quick breakdown prior to hydrogenation to formates [32], bidentate carbonates are not visible. The presence of a shoulder band at 1610 cm−1 which is generally associated with monodentate formates, is significant. Research has shown that the hydrogenation of monodentate carbonates results in monodentate formates and the hydrogenation of bidentate bicarbonates results in bidentate formates [35,36]. Although theoretical evidence was provided by Taherian et al. [37], the reduced stability and increased reactivity of monodentate formates has rendered them difficult to identify. Hence the need for further investigations over this observed trend; therefore, the results of in-situ FTIR analysis shows that the 1.5 % Ni-MCM-41/MgO- Pr2O3 catalyst catalyzes CO2 methanation via the formate pathway, albeit with CO* as a byproduct rather than an intermediate, the CO2* adsorbed species produce CO*, which may not be further hydrogenated to methane. Furthermore, the calculated relative concentrations of gaseous CH4, adsorbed CO, and bidentate formates, according to the operando DRIFT data, depict the evolution of the gaseous and adsorbed species as a function of temperature. Adsorbed CO was measured by integrating bands between 2100 and 1750 cm−1, whereas formates and CH4 were measured by tracking the intensity of bands at 1572 and 3015 cm−1 [38]. To obtain a normalized average concentration between 200 and 350 °C, the maximum value determined for each species was adjusted to 100 %. Fig. 7 b shows that for the 1.5 % Ni-MCM-41/MgO- Pr2O3, the formates gradually conversion decreased from 100 to 70.1 % as the temperature increased from 220 to 250 °C, while the adsorbed carbon monoxide and methane increase from 21.3 to 65.1 % and 1.56 to 16.93 %, respectively. These differences show that at first, formate conversion is dominated by the dissociation of formates into the adsorbed carbon monoxide. The rate at which methane is produced is greatly increased by the hydrogenation procedures above 250 °C. At 275 °C, the adsorption of CO attains its maximum and is burnt to produce methane. The amount of adsorbed molecules CH4 and CO both changed with temperature, therefore, the rate-limiting processes in methane generation are the dissociation of CO and hydrogenation of CH4 [38]. Additionally, CO2 methanation at Ni-MCM-41/MgO- Pr2O3 concentration greater than 1.5 % favors the direct hydrogenation of formate (formate → CH4) over the formate dissociation followed by the hydrogenation of adsorbed CO (formate → CO → CH4). When the 1.5 % Ni-MCM-41/MgO- Pr2O3 is heated to 225 °C, a key intermediate species is generated, such that at temperatures over 275 °C, the specises undergoes decomposition into gaseous methane and adsorbed CO (particularly the bridged type). 3.10.2 CO2 methanation mechanisms on the1.5 % Ni-MCM-41/MgO- Pr2O3 surface by DFT calculations The associative mechanisms involving formate have been shown to be likely significant for CO2 methanation in some investigations [32,33]. As a result, studying the role of the formate route in CO2 methanation over the 1.5 % Ni-MCM-41/MgO- Pr2O3 catalyst is essential. Fig. 7a depicts the energy spectrum of CO2 methanation via the formate route. Table 3 provides a compilation of the reaction energies ( Δ E ) and activation energy ( E a ) barriers for a variety of basic processes. To begin with, a hydrogen molecule is adsorbed and then is rapidly dissociated onto the Ni-MCM-41 site (CO2* + H2* structure), thus providing a supply of H for the CO2 hydrogenation reaction. Eventually, CO2* becomes HCOOH* after being hydrogenated into HCOO*. HCOO* and HCOOH* with activation energy equivalents of 88.32 and 172.42 kJ/mol. The activation energies required to generate HCOO* and HCOOH* are approximately 32.63 and 17.02 kJ/mol, making them somewhat endergonic (Fig. 7a). The H2COOH* species is produced when the C atom of HCOOH* abstracts an additional H atom and interacts with it. The activation energy barrier for this H-abstraction process is 70.92 kJ/mol, making it exothermic with the release of - 47.02 kJ/mol of energy. When H* reacts with H2COOH*, it breaks it down into H2CO* and H2O*. The breakdown of H2COOH* is an exothermic reaction with a high E a = 283.67 kJ/mol. There are two possible hydrogenation paths for H2CO* after H2O* desorption, where either H2COH* or H3CO* may be produced. The terminal oxygen of H2CO* is protonated to generate H2COH* in the H2COH* production route (please see red line of Fig. 7a). There is a greater activation energy barrier, at 254.90 kJ/mol. H2COH* eventually breaks down into CH2* and OH*. Table 3 reveals that the E a required for the breakdown of H2COH* is 160.99 kJ/mol, making it a very exothermic process. After reacting with H* to produce H2O*, the OH* that was formed desorbs from the catalyst's surface. It is endergonic for the generation of H2O* and to desorb it requires about 9.39 and 64.07 kJ/mol, respectively. The activation energy barrier for H2O* production is 65.45 kJ/mol. The CH2* formed from the breakdown of H2COH* is first hydrogenated to CH3* and then to CH4* once H2O* is adsorbed. The energy barriers to CH3* and CH4* production require 25.92 and 118.91 kJ/mol of activation energy equivalents, respectively. The H3CO* species are formed by additional protonation of the C atom of H2CO* along the H3CO* production pathway (see the blue line in Fig. 7a). The reacting H3CO* species with H* yields CH3* and OH* (CH3* + OH*, Table 3), with an E a of 116.72 kJ/mol and a low measure of exothermicity of 10.28 kJ.mol−1. The E a barrier for H-assisted H3CO* breaks down to yield higher amounts of CH3* and OH* at 321.96 kJ/mol. The reaction between H* and OH* yields H2O* after this barrier is overcome. As soon as more hydrogen is added to CH3*, the latter is converted to CH4*. The activation energy barrier for the H3CO* emergence route is relatively high (i.e., 321.96 kJ/mol) (see Fig. 7a for a comparison with the H2COH* formation pathway). Thus, for CO2 methanation via formate intermediate, H2COH* production is recommended. Thus, results from the DFT calculations and in situ DRIFTS analysis are consistent, which further suggests that CO2 methanation takes place via the formate pathway. 3.10.3 Kinetic studies To further compare the kinetic data of the 1.5 %Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3 catalyst for different CO2 conversions, kinetic data were generated (Fig. 7b). The degree to which reaction rates depend on the concentrations of CO2/H2 in the catalyst can be inferred from the differing reaction orders for both H2 and CO2. The obvious energy barriers for both paths over the catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation are identical in lieu of their emanation from alternative reaction routes. Highly scattered nickel particles on 1.5 % Ni-MCM-41/MgO- Pr2O3 can give substantial supports that help in increasing the catalyst's active sites, thus resulting in a better reaction rate for the methanation of CO2. Increased nickel dispersion with decreased particle size improves the dissociation and adsorption of hydrogen, which in turn provides a greater number of H atoms for the hydrogenation and generation of O2 vacancies (Fig. 7b). Increasing the concentration of the O2 vacancy in MgO- Pr2O3, increases its basic reactivity, which further increases its capacity to adsorb and activate carbon dioxide formation and conversion. CO migration and H2 leakage in the interfacial region are both expedited by the greater Ni- MgO- Pr2O3 contact. Some compared literature on CO2 methanation via catalysts are presented in Table 4 . 4 Conclusion This study investigates the influence of MgO-Pr2O3 as a support material on the catalytic performance of Ni/MCM-41 for the process of CO2 methanation. The hydrothermal synthesis method was used to prepare the catalysts with different %Ni loading onto MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3. The results show that the conversion of CO2 and CH4 selectivity of the promoted catalysts were influenced by the concentrations of MgO, Pr2O3, as well as the distribution of metal active sites and basic sites. At temperature and pressure of 400 °C and 1 atm, with a GHSV of 3000 and 9000 mL/g/h, the 1.5 %Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3 displayed the most effective catalytic activity, in terms of maximum methane selectivity and carbon dioxide conversion of 99.9 and 87.4 %, respectively. The high Ni dispersion and an intimate contact between Ni and MCM-41 promoted with MgO-Pr2O3 is responsible for the high catalytic activity for CO2 methanation. The DRIFTS experiments and DFT results showed that CO2 methanation reaction occurs via formate conversion and not via CO which eventually dissociates to release methane from the surface of the catalyst support. The catalyst was also found to be stable over a 30 h-period. coredata.dc:description: One way to solve environmental and energy related problems is to use carbon dioxide as a raw material along with renewable H2 to make useful chemicals and goods from those alternative energy sources. Several compositions of xNi-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3 were used for CO2 methanation via the hydrothermal synthesis method. Techniques such as TEM, H2-TPD, XRD, SEM, and BET were used to study the influence of the mechanism of the catalyst during CO2 methanation. The best performance was obtained for the 1.5 % Ni-MCM-41/MgO-Pr2O3 catalyst at 400 °C and normal atmospheric pressure, where the CO2 conversion efficiency and selectivity were 87.4 and 99.9 %, respectively. It was thought that the synergistic effects between the Ni active sites, the promoter, and the support were important for the high reactivity of the catalysts. These effects included better Ni dispersion and more CO2 adsorption sites due to the inclusion of MgO-Pr2O3. The promoted catalyst retained its high reactivity after 30 h on stream as observed during the stability test.
coredata.dc:title: Ni catalysts modified with mesoporous silica support: The role of Pr2O3 and MgO on the methanation of CO2
